questions.text: Which statement helps to differentiate rigidity from spasticity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by a lesion in the pyramidal tract

options.label: C
options.text: It affects both flexor and extensor muscles

options.label: D
options.text: More resistance in one direction than in the other direction

questions.correct_answer: C. It affects both flexor and extensor muscles
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - It affects both flexor and extensor mu

Spasticity

Rigidity
  • Caused by lesions in the pyramidal tract
  • Seen in extrapyramidal lesions
  • It is velocity- dependent (i.e. more noticeable with fast movements)
  • Velocity independent- does not vary with the speed of movement of muscle groups involved
  • Predominantly affects one group of muscle (generally antigravity muscle).
  • More resistance in one direction in the other direction
  • Affect both groups (flexor and extensor) of muscle.
  • If an upper limb is contracted because of paralysis, if we try to open the limb, more tone in the initial part of involvement, suddenly resistance will decrease, and the arm will open - “Clasp knife spasticity”.
  • Clasp knife spasticity is due to activation of the Golgi tendon organ.
  • Weakness present
  • Hypertonia throughout the range of motion
  • Lead pipe rigidity (neuroleptic malignant)- There is a uniform increase in tone, tension is high throughout the range of motion.
  • Cogwheel rigidity (Parkinson’s)- Tremor superimposed on this hypertonia that results in an intermittent increase in tone during the movement.
  • Cogwheel rigidity = Lead pipe rigidity + tremors

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic with congenital ptosis and abnormal movements of the upper eyelid that occur with jaw movements such as chewing . options.text: Aberrant innervation between the oculomotor and trigeminal nerves

questions.correct_answer: B. Aberrant innervation between the oculomotor and trigeminal nerves
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B –

Condition

Features

Isolated congenital ptosis
  • Developmental myopathy of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle

Blepharophimosis syndrome
  • Ptosis
  • Telecanthus (increased distance between the two medial canthus)
  • Epicanthus inversus
  • Shortening of horizontal palpebral fissure
  • Ectropion

Marcus Gunn/jaw winking syndrome
  • Synkinesis: abnormal movements of the upper eyelid with jaw movements (e.g., chewing) (ptosis decreases with jaw movement)
  • Congenital ptosis with abnormal movements of the upper lid with jaw movements
  • Abnormal connections between the trigeminal nerve (5th nerve) and oculomotor nerve (3rd nerve)
  • Simultaneous contraction of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and lateral pterygoids

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed: What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sig

Role of Plain X-ray/CT scan
  • Holmann Miller sign: Anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Hondusa's sign: increase in distance between maxillary sinus and mandible on CTscan.
  • Opacification of sphenoid sinus.

Role of CECT scan
  • CTdiagnosis is based on two constant features:

i. Mass in the nose and pterygopalatine fossa.

ii. Erosion of bone behind the sphenopalatine foramen at the root of the pterygoid plate.

  • When the wedge of pterygoid is eroded so the medial and lateral pterygoid plate look like a separate plate, that is called Chopstick sign.

Role of MRI
  • MRI accesses the relation of the tumor to the critical structures such as the internal carotid artery, cavernous sinus and pituitary gland.
  • Recurrent and residual tumors are the best appreciated on the MRI

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the definition of steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period

options.label: C
options.text: More than 3 relapses in any 12 months

options.label: D
options.text: Two consecutive relapses within 3 weeks of its discontinuation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid th

Remission

Urine albumin nil or trace (or proteinuria <4 mg/m2/h) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens.

Relapse

Urine albumin 3+ or 4+ (or proteinuria > 40 mg/m2/h) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens, after having been in remission previously.

Frequent relapses

Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period or more than 3 relapses in any 12 months.

Steroid dependence

Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy or within 14 days of its discontinuation.

Steroid resistance

Absence of remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/d for 4 weeks.

  • Chest physiotherapy

Type IV

Decreased perfusion of respiratory muscles
  • ET tube with IPPV

Respiratory Failure

Examples

Management

Type I

ARDS, CHF
  • Low volume ventilation
  • Prone position and neuromuscular blockage

Type II

Status asthmaticus, acute exacerbation of COPD
  • Tight fitting face mask (NIV)
  • ET tube with IPPV - If due to diaphragmatic paralysis

Type III

Peri-operative atelectasis
  • O2 supplementation
  • Chest physiotherapy

Type IV

Decreased perfusion of respiratory muscles
  • ET tube with IPPV

questions.text: A 32-year-old female named Sarah recently survived a severe car accident. She was trapped in the wreckage for several hours before being rescued. Since the accident, she has been experiencing recurrent distressing dreams about the event, avoiding driving or even being near cars, and constantly feeling on edge. Which of the following best describes Sarah's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C : Hypervigilance and avoidance behavior.

Post traumatic stress disorder

Definition

Stress disorder occurring after exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. Symptoms last more than a month.

Symptoms

MAHI: Mood and cognitive symptoms, Avoidance, Hyperarousal, Intrusion symptoms.

Delayed Expression

Symptoms may appear after 6 months of trauma.

Structural Changes

PTSD is associated with structural changes in the Hippocampus and Amygdala.

Risk Factors

Female gender, Childhood trauma, Poor social support, Stressful life changes, Family history of psychiatric illness, Certain personality disorder traits.

Treatment

Pharmacotherapy (SSRIs), Psychotherapy (CBT, EMDR).

Complex PTSD

New diagnosis in ICD 11, associated with repetitive and severe stressors. Additional symptoms include affect regulation problems and difficulties in relationships.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painful, recurrent abscesses and nodules in the axillary and groin regions. The lesions are interconnected and often lead to the formation of tunnels and scarring. There is a notable history of these symptoms recurring for more than six months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these clinical features?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Hidradenitis suppurativ

Aspect

Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS)

Definition

Chronic inflammatory condition affecting the whole hair unit

Common Names

Acne inversa, HS, or "Inverse acne"

Age Group

Pubertal individuals,more common in females 

Affected Areas

Axilla, groin, mammary, umbilicus, buttocks

Clinical Presentation
  • Deep-seated painful nodules
  • Abscesses
  • Draining sinuses
  • Bridged scar
  • Polyporus comedones
  • Inflammatory papules
  • Recurrent episodes of abscesses, multiple discharge sinuses, heals with scarring (Bridging/rope scars) of

Pathophysiology

Diagnosis
  • Primarily clinical, based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of lesions.
  • Biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Additionally, HS is often categorized into different stages (Hurley staging system) based on the severity of the condition, which can guide treatment decisions

Risk Factors

Obesity, smoking, diabetes, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome

Associations
  • Follicular occlusion triad (hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), acne conglobata, and dissecting cellulitis of the scalp)
  • Tetrad (FO triad + pilonidal sinus)
  • Crohn's disease

Treatment
  • Weight reduction
  • Diet modifications
  • Smoking cessation
  • Analgesics
  • Antibiotics
  • Anti-inflammatory agents
  • Retinoids
  • Biologicals (e.g., Adalimumab)
  • Surgical therapy (if recurrent)

Feature

Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Alternative Names

Post Infectious Glomerulonephritis / Acute Proliferative Glomerulonephritis

Causative Agent

Streptococcus Pyogenes (Group A β Hemolytic streptococcus): Strain 12, 4, 1

Incubation Period

1-4 weeks

Clinical Features

Initially the patient develops sore throat or Skin infection due to Streptococcus leading to Type 3 Hypersensitivity reaction which in turn causes PSGN (Cola coloured urine)

  • Antibodies: Anti-DNAse B (preferred), Antistreptolysin O (ASO)

Flea-bitten appearance

Light Microscopy
  • Increase in endothelial cells.
  • Increase in mesangial cells.
  • Increase in neutrophils.
  • Increase in macrophages.
  • Hypercellular glomeruli noted

Immunofluorescence

Starry sky appearance

Treatment

Antibiotics (usually penicillin or other appropriate antibiotics to eliminate the streptococcal infection)

Correct Option C - CASR mutation:

 

Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid

Genetic Mutations
  • BRAF V600E mutation: Most common mutation in PTC.
  • RET-PTC fusion: Resulting from a translocation (t(10:17)).
  • NTRK mutation: Associated with PTC.

Other Risk Factors
  • History of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Long-standing thyroglossal cyst.
  • History of radiation exposure (may manifest years later).

Clinical Features
  • Anterior neck nodule.
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Lymphatic spread (except for follicular carcinoma).

Microscopic Characteristics
  • Fingerlike projections (true papilla).
